Header.Title: Federal R&D Award Persistent Identifier System Strategic Plan
Header.Description: Strategy to implement Section 4 of the 2022 OSTP Public Access Memo requiring persistent digital identifiers for all federal R&D awards via a unified website and database serving as the authoritative PID resolver.
Header.Publisher: National Science and Technology Council (NSTC) Subcommittee on Open Science

Organization.Name: General Services Administration (GSA)
Organization.Description: Lead implementing agency responsible for operating the unified federal R&D award PID system.

StrategicPlan.Vision: A transparent, interoperable, and trusted national system in which every federally funded R&D award is linked to a single, globally unique, persistent, machine-resolvable, and machine-processable URL connecting federal investments to researchers, institutions, outputs, and impacts.
StrategicPlan.Mission: To develop and operate a government-wide, publicly accessible platform that aggregates authoritative information on all extramural and intramural federal R&D awards, harmonizes metadata across agency systems, and assigns each award a universal persistent identifier (PID) in the form of a stable, resolvable URL.

Stakeholder.Name: Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP)

Goal.Name: Establish a Single, Unified Federal R&D Award Database

Objective.Name: Build a centralized website and data platform
Objective.Description: Aggregate authoritative award data from USASpending, agency systems, and intramural sources into a unified database.

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: System architecture published within 6 months.
100% of covered agencies connected via standardized ingest APIs.

Objective.Name: Harmonize metadata schemas
Objective.Description: Develop a unified Federal Award Metadata Standard aligned with PID interoperability requirements.

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: Metadata standard approved by the NSTC Subcommittee on Open Science.
95% of ingested awards include required core metadata fields.

Goal.Name: Assign a Unique, Persistent URL-Based PID to Every R&D Award

Objective.Name: Generate persistent URL PIDs automatically
Objective.Description: Issue stable URLs such as https://awards.gov/award/{UUID} for all awards.

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: 100% of new awards receive a PID at time of publication.
All legacy awards (2008–present) assigned PIDs within 24 months.

Objective.Name: Ensure long-term persistence and resolvability
Objective.Description: Maintain resolver infrastructure independent of agency-specific numbering systems.

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: Resolver uptime ≥ 99.9%.
No PID ever reissued or deleted.

Goal.Name: Integrate PIDs for People, Organizations, and Research Outputs

Objective.Name: Associate award metadata with ORCID iDs

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: ≥ 70% of awards include at least one verified ORCID iD.
≥ 90% match rate for institution affiliations.

Objective.Name: Link award PIDs to research outputs (DOIs, PMIDs, datasets)

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: Research output auto-linking operational within 12 months.

Goal.Name: Provide a Public, Machine-Actionable PID Resolver Service

Objective.Name: Implement landing pages with structured metadata

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: Schema.org compliance validated quarterly.
Landing page load time < 1.5 seconds.
REST and GraphQL API deployed within 12 months.

Goal.Name: Support Subaward and Hierarchical Award Modeling

Objective.Name: Reference subawards by parent award PID

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: 100% of subawards include parent_award_pid.
Metadata schema for multi-agency funding deployed in Year 2.

Objective.Name: Issue OMB-approved guidance establishing the PID system as authoritative

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: OMB memo issued within 12 months.
Steering group charter finalized and published.

Goal.Name: Reduce Costs and Avoid Redundant PID Infrastructure

Objective.Name: Use low-cost URL-based PIDs rather than DOI minting for every award

PerformanceIndicators.PerformanceIndicator: PID cost per award < $0.001.
Measured reduction in duplicative DOI assignment.
